Authors:
Josefina Viejobueno, Berta de los Santos, Miguel
Camacho-Sanchez, Ana Aguado, Maria Camacho, Sergio Miguel Salazar
Title:
Phenotypic variability and genetic diversity of the
pathogenic fungus Macrophomina phaseolina from several hosts contrasts
with marked host-specific virulence on strawberry
Abstract:
Macrophomina phaseolina, causal agent of charcoal rot
disease, is a pathogenic soil-borne fungus that affects more than 500
plant species, causing various types of disease to several crops,
including crown and root rot of strawberry. A deeper knowledge on the
diversity of M. phaseolina, is useful to design control strategies for
this disease. Morphological, physiological, genetic and phytopathogenic
parameters were evaluated among 32 isolates of M. phaseolina from
different hosts occurring in Argentina and Spain. Colony
characteristics, average size of microsclerotia, chlorate phenotype and
mycelial growth at different temperatures (5 º- 40 °C), and pH (3.0 -
8.0) were recorded. The morphological and physiological traits were
heterogeneous and did not show any association with the genetic
structure nor with their pathogenicity. Most of the isolates (71.9 %)
exhibited chlorate sensitive phenotype. The optimal growth temperature
range was between 25 °C and 35 °C, and the optimal pH varied between 4.0
and 6.0. The genetic structure analyzed with four DNA markers (EF-1α,
ITS, CAL and TUB) showed a little diversity among isolates of M.
phaseolina, with no clear association with the country of origin, but a
significant association with the host. Based on its phylogenetic
affinity, one isolate was reclassified as M. pseudophaseolina. The
latter did not show noticeable phenotypic differences compared to the
other isolates of M. phaseolina, except for having an optimal growth
temperature 5-10 °C lower. Pathogenicity tests on strawberry plants
revealed marked host specificity, being the isolates obtained from
strawberry more virulent than those from other hosts.
